title: What is the importance of science and technology in education? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s vital. Science and technology are everywhere around us in the world — in my computer science presentations I often point out that it’s hard to buy a combine for a farm that doesn’t come with the tech to drive itself around the field making its own algorithmic choices to maximize yield. And understanding how things work, at least at a basic chemistry and physics level, is key. But as Tony Histbook also points out, those can’t exist in a vacuum. A major aim of school is indeed to prepare students for future careers in the world of work, but another is to make informed, active citizens out of them. You can’t do that without a grounding in the language arts, without a solid appreciation of social studies, etc. One of the most important resources to our education system, one that people tend to overlook, is time. Kansas, where I live and work, actually has one of the longest mandated school years at 1116 hours grades 1–11. Yet that’s all you have: 1116 hours. Sounds like a lot, but it’s really not all that much if you insist on teaching literature, writing, history, science, math, computers, tech, cursive, driving a stick shift, home ec, and everything else somebody thinks is important. At lower grades take out home ec and driving but replace with cursive, shoe-tying, and everything else the parents don’t have time to teach. So…science and tech…absolutely, a vital part of the curriculum. Just like all the other vital parts.

It is impossible to disagree, at this point in time, that there is no use of technology in education. In fact, technology is often used in school, but many people happen to skim over those relatively minor uses. Here are some of those, although there are countless more: 1. A tool for students to use in class - Many students are not able to afford laptops or iPads for themselves. Even if they are, many are not able to bring those devices to school. Because of technological advancements that have allowed those devices to become more prevalent, smaller, and cheaper, schools can utilize the technology. Therefore, schools and teachers can purchase computers or tablets for the use of the students. Devices like these become extremely useful for research, but also for class discussion (both of which I’ll get to in a bit). 2. Services like Google Classroom (School to Home connection) - Technology often helps bridge the productivity gap between home and school. For example, homework no longer has to be exclusively physical since it can be assigned digitally through programs like Google Classroom. In addition, Classroom can administer tests or quizzes to the student while they are at home or at school. 3. Studying - Along with an exponential increase in homework and overall school difficulty recently, there has been an increase of digital programs that are meant to help students study for upcoming assignments. An example is Quizlet. Quizlet helps with creating study sets, or combinations of terms and definitions, for the user to go over. It mainly represents the transfusion of education and technological productivity because the new technology is able to aid the student advance their education. 4. Kahoot.it - Kahoot is a service that allows teachers to create small quizzes for the members of a class to take together. As I said earlier, technology is helping to connect the students to the class and aid in class discussions. Kahoot uses a mobile device to enable the students to take those mini-quizzes and learn more in class. 5. School to Home Communication - There’s one thing that Google Classroom lacks - and that’s a dedicated connection, communication-wise, between school and home. Since it is considered inappropriate for a student to directly communicate with his or her students, Remind was created. Remind acts as a buffer app that allows the teachers to send messages to students and for students to ask for help. Incidentally, Remind can act through the normal messaging app anyway. Either way, technology can help educate students outside of school as well. 6. Databases - Without database software, schools would be a huge hassle to run. For example, the school I attend uses an integrated program to manage grades and attendance together so it is not too hard for them to manage. Physically writing names, grades, and attendance would be extremely difficult for the school to manage, so database software is much more efficient. 7. Researching - For almost every level of education, from primary to college-level, researching is a must. Technology has allowed people to utilize the internet to spread information and find research, which is essential to an unbiased and wholesome education. 8. VR - As I wrote about in a another answer, VR also helps in education. For example, a High School group is using VR to create a virtual lab to help educate people that can’t access or don’t wish to physically access certain chemicals. 9. Test-Taking - Taking tests on quizzes not only saves paper and time but also tends to be more adaptable. Online tests allow the computer to change the difficulty of the test, edit the question order, and more. This helps prevent cheating and is also useful for diagnostic tests like NWEA MAP or practice tests. 10. Google Drive - Cloud services are useful to education, even more so than Google Drive, because they are dedicated platforms for the students to bring digital assignments home or to school. In addition, the “share” feature also allows students to turn in assignments.  In conclusion, the collision of Education and Technology are essentially benefiting from and promoting each other.
